questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient was walking up stairs at work when he suddenly collapsed in the stairwell. The patient describes the pain as “an elephant sitting on my chest” with associated shortness of breath. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 154/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. Initial examination demonstrates a diaphoretic male in moderate distress clutching the front of his chest. An initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following cardiac vessels most likely requires revascularization?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple comorbidities and cardiovascular risk factors presents with classic features of acute coronary syndrome, including exertional chest pressure not relieved with rest. His initial electrocardiogram meets the criteria for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), with notable elevations in the anterolateral leads of the heart with reciprocal depressions inferiorly. Given these findings, this patient most likely has occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery.   

Myocardial infarction is defined by irreversible necrosis of heart muscle secondary to prolonged ischemia. Clinically, this condition most commonly presents with chest pressure or pain radiating to the arm/jaw with associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, and nausea or vomiting. On electrocardiography, a STEMI can be recognized by the presence of ST-elevations in one or more contiguous leads with reciprocal depressions of corresponding leads.  

The three most commonly occluded vessels include the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), the right coronary artery (RCA), and the left circumflex coronary artery (LCX). These areas correspond to the anterior, inferior, and lateral anatomic regions of the heart, respectively. In most cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the right coronary artery (right dominant circulation). However, in a subset of cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the left circumflex coronary artery (left dominant circulation) or from the RCA and LCX (codominant circulation).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Left anterior descending coronary artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior descending coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior descending coronary artery manifests with ST-depressions in V1-V3 and tall R-waves. A posterior ECG will demonstrate elevations in V7-V9, confirming the diagnosis. 
❌ Right coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the right coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations of the inferior leads and reciprocal changes in the anterior leads. 
❌ Left circumflex coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left circumflex coronary artery manifests with ST elevations or q-waves in lead I or aVL. 
❌ Obtuse marginal artery :
Incorrect: Like infarctions of the left circumflex coronary artery, infarction of the obtuse marginal artery results in a lateral STEMI pattern on ECG–with elevations or q-waves in leads I, aVL, or V5-V6.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after having multiple syncopal episodes at home. Over several hours, the patient endorses intermittent, substernal chest pressure radiating to her right jaw. She was recently admitted to the hospital two weeks ago following an acute myocardial infarction with stent placement. Since discharge, the patient has occasionally forgotten to take her medications. She has a medical history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s medications include metformin, lisinopril, carvedilol, aspirin, and clopidogrel. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 46/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 97/66 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. A screening electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following cardiac vessels is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease process?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates complete heart block–as evidenced by dyssynchrony between p-waves, QRS complexes, and t-waves. Given this pattern of findings, the most likely implicated coronary artery is the right coronary artery, which contains branches that supply the conducting SA and AV nodes of the heart. In addition, the history of a recent myocardial infarction and medication noncompliance is concerning for in-stent thrombosis requiring revascularization.  

When the AV node is damaged secondary to ischemia, the regular conduction pattern of the heart fails, resulting in independent and asynchronous contractions of the atria and ventricles. When this occurs, bradycardia ensues (the ventricles contract independently at an average rate of 40-45 bpm), manifesting with exertional syncope, angina, or shortness of breath.    

In addition to RCA occlusion, distal left coronary artery occlusion–particularly of the anterior interventricular branch of the LCA–can also result in complete heart block, as this artery contributes to the blood supply of the AV bundle.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right coronary artery :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior descending coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior descending artery manifests with ST-depressions in V1-V3 and tall R-waves. A posterior ECG will demonstrate elevations in V7-V9, confirming the diagnosis. While this artery is most commonly a branch of the RCA, it is not always implicated in SA or AV node dysfunction–especially if it branches from the LCX.  
❌ Left anterior descending coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left anterior descending coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations of the anterior and lateral leads.
❌ Left circumflex coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left circumflex coronary artery manifests with ST elevations or q-waves in the lead I or aVL. 
❌ Obtuse marginal artery :
Incorrect: Like infarctions of the left circumflex coronary artery, infarction of the obtuse marginal artery results in a lateral STEMI pattern on ECG–with elevations or q-waves in leads I, aVL, or V5-V6.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with exertional chest pressure and is found to have complex, multi-vessel coronary artery disease. His past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, end-stage renal disease, and a thirty-pack-year smoking history. After discussing options, the patient elects to have a coronary artery bypass graft operation. A vessel from which of the anatomic locations is preferred for this patient’s procedure?

choices.text: An artery from the left thoracic wall
An artery from the radial aspect of the forearm
A vein from the medial calf
An artery from the ulnar aspect of the forearm
A vein from the medial neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a coronary artery bypass graft  (CABG) operation, a procedure in which diseased coronary arteries are bypassed using native, healthy blood vessels. The primary indications for this procedure include disabling angina despite maximum medical therapy, significant stenosis (> 70%) of the proximal left anterior descending artery with 2-vessel or 3-vessel disease, primary left main coronary artery disease, or multivessel coronary artery disease with high anatomic complexity.  

In general, arterial grafts are preferred over venous grafts due to their durability and decreased risk of thrombosis compared with venous grafts. The most commonly harvested arterial grafts are internal thoracic and radial arteries. The great saphenous vein continues to be harvested for some patients requiring CABG.    



Option Analysis

✅ An artery from the left thoracic wall:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ An artery from the radial aspect of the forearm:
Incorrect: The radial artery has been increasingly used as an arterial graft for coronary artery bypass grafting; however, it should not be accessed in patients with underlying end-stage renal disease, as it precludes the use of the ipsilateral arm for dialysis access grafting. 
❌ A vein from the medial calf:
Incorrect: In general, arterial grafts are preferred due to their longevity and lower propensity towards thrombosis. The saphenous vein may be utilized when arterial grafts are non-accessible. 
❌ An artery from the ulnar aspect of the forearm:
Incorrect: The ulnar artery is not routinely used in coronary artery bypass grafting. 
❌ A vein from the medial neck:
Incorrect: The jugular veins and arteries are not used for coronary artery bypass grafting.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of hypertension. The patient was seen in the emergency department last week for a laceration repair, and her systolic blood pressure was noted to be over 200 mmHg. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 225/102 mmHg in the right upper extremity and 210/97 in the left upper extremity. The patient has a 2/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. The patient’s lower extremities have scant hair bilaterally, and a brachiofemoral pulse delay is noted bilaterally. A portion of the patient’s chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has uncontrolled hypertension, which is the most common presentation for adult patients with undiagnosed coarctation of the aorta. Clues to this diagnosis include an systolic ejection murmur (indicative of a bicuspid aortic valve), brachiofemoral pulse delay, and rib notching noted in the chest radiograph above.  

Coarctation of the aorta is an overall common congenital anomaly, accounting for approximately 6-8% of all congenital heart disease. This anatomic defect refers to a discrete narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. The degree of defect varies amongst individuals. The condition has a high association with Turner syndrome and a bicuspid aortic valve.   

Due to the stenosis, patients develop hypertension in the upper extremities, diminished blood pressure in the lower extremities, and brachiofemoral pulse delay. In the thorax, notching of the posterior one-third of the third to eighth ribs occurs due to erosion caused by the formation of large collaterals in the intercostal arteries.  

Option Analysis

✅ Coarctation of the aorta :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral vascular disease :
Incorrect: Peripheral vascular disease can result in diminished or absent hair on the lower extremities. However, this condition would not account for the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph.   
❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm :
Incorrect: An abdominal aortic aneurysm more commonly presents in patients with a long history of smoking and atherosclerotic disease. This diagnosis would not explain the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph. 
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy more commonly presents with signs of congestive heart failure, such as lower extremity edema, shortness of breath, and an S3 heart sound. This patient’s heart sound indicates a possible bicuspid aortic valve.
❌ Subclavian artery stenosis :
Incorrect: Subclavian steal syndrome refers to a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery. It can manifest with exercise-induced ischemia of the affected limb.

questions.text: A five-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician to evaluate recurrent ear infections and sinusitis. The parent states, “He always seems to be sick with something. Every week, he is coughing or tugging on his ear. His nose runs constantly.” The patient was born full-term without complications during pregnancy or delivery. He has no other medical problems and does not take any medications daily. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear nasal secretions and hyperemia of the nasal mucosa bilaterally. After appropriate work-up and first-line medication trials, a nasal mucosa biopsy is performed and sent for transmission electron microscopy. Upon analysis of the specimen, the patient is found to have an absence of dynein arms on microtubule assemblies. Which of the following cardiac anomalies is most likely to be present given this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Apex of the heart located in the right chest
Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle
Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum

questions.solution:
This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia (sometimes known as Karatagener syndrome), which arises due to defective dynein arms of the microtubule, resulting in impaired ciliary function. Ciliary dysfunction manifests as recurrent sinopulmonary infections, infertility (secondary to immotile sperm or immotile fallopian cilia), and bronchiectasis. This condition is highly associated with situs inversus, an embryological folding defect in which the thoracic and abdominal viscera are transposed across the midline (including the heart, a phenomenon termed dextrocardia).  

Patients with dextrocardia (whether in isolation or in association with situs inversus) will often have a palpable apex heartbeat over the right chest. On screening electrocardiogram, patients will have evidence of right axis deviation, inversion of all complexes in lead I, upright p waves in AVL, and an absent R wave progression in the anterior leads. A chest x-ray will demonstrate the apex of the heart in the right chest.  

It should be noted that when the condition occurs in isolation, dextrocardia is often associated with additional, more severe cardiac anomalies as compared to situs inversus, which is typically benign and often diagnosed incidentally.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Apex of the heart located in the right chest :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets into the right ventricle :
Incorrect: Ebstein anomaly is caused by in utero exposure to lithium. This condition is also associated with tricuspid regurgitation and isolated right heart failure. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular cardiac septum :
Incorrect: This answer describes Tetralogy of Fallot, the most common cause of early childhood cyanosis. This condition more commonly presents with tet-spells–episodes of cyanosis on exertion resulting from right to left shunting. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Transpositioned aorta and pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: Transposition of the great vessels is a rare congenital cardiac defect that results in death within the first few months of life if untreated. It is not associated with ciliary dysfunction or upper respiratory infections. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.
❌ Tricuspid atresia :
Incorrect: Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of a tricuspid valve, with a subsequently hypoplastic right ventricle. This condition requires both a ventricular septal and atrial septal defect for survival. This patient likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia, which is instead associated with situs inversus.

questions.text: A 5-day-old female neonate is evaluated in the nursery for a heart murmur. She was born at 36-weeks gestational age to a 27-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, mother via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Family history is notable for atrial fibrillation in her father. Vitals are within normal limits. Cardiac examination reveals a holosystolic machine-like murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular region. Pulmonary and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. An echocardiogram is performed which confirms the patient’s diagnosis. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This preterm neonate with a holosystolic machine-like murmur in the left infraclavicular area most likely has a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which occurs when the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. Preterm babies are at increased risk of having a PDA. Other risk factors include congenital rubella syndrome and chromosomal abnormalities.  

The condition presents with a continuous machine-like murmur most prominent at the left infraclavicular area. In addition, patients can develop differential cyanosis, wherein the lower extremities are cyanotic, but the upper extremities are acyanotic. Echocardiogram is performed to confirm the presence of clinically significant PDA.  

Indomethacin, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication, blocks the synthesis of prostaglandin E and is used to close the PDA. If this fails, surgical intervention is needed. In contrast, prostaglandin E can be used to keep the ductus arteriosus open. 

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of prostaglandin E :
Incorrect: Prostaglandin E is used to keep ductus arteriosus open. This treatment is necessary in certain patients, such as those with transposition of the great vessels, who need the shunt to survive. However, this patient most likely has an isolated PDA (given the echocardiogram confirmation), and medications should be administered to close the defect. 
❌ Referral for surgical intervention :
Incorrect: Surgical ligation is not the first-line treatment in patients with a PDA because surgical intervention can cause potential complications including infection, hemodynamic instability, and respiratory compromise. Surgery is generally reserved for patients who have failed medical management. 
✅ Administration of indomethacin :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Order chest radiograph :
Incorrect: This patient has a patent ductus arteriosus. Her condition has already been confirmed by echocardiography. A chest radiograph is less sensitive and specific. Hence, it would not provide additional information about the patient’s condition. 
❌ Administration of propranolol :
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used to manage patients with atrial fibrillation. This patient has a family history of atrial fibrillation. However, the physical examination finding of a machine-like murmur is more consistent with the diagnosis of PDA.

questions.text:
Full-term twin girls are delivered vaginally at 37 weeks 5 days gestation. There was appropriate prenatal care and there were no significant complications during the pregnancy. The infants are taken to the newborn nursery for evaluation. Twin A is 90th percentile for weight and twin B is 23rd percentile for weight. Vital signs are appropriate for age. On examination, twin A is ruddy and dusky whereas twin B is pale. Cardiopulmonary examination in both infants is normal. Lab work is obtained, and results are shown below. Which of the following most likely was a feature of the pregnancy or the delivery? 

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Twin A    
 Hemoglobin     18.1 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     52.9%    
 Leukocyte count     17,600/mm3    
 Platelet count     190,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     108 fL    
 Reticulocyte count     3.0%    
 Coombs test     Negative    
 Peripheral smear     Normal    
 Twin B    
 Hemoglobin     9.8 g/dL    
 Hematocrit      28.8%    
 Leukocyte count     15,7000/mm3    
 Platelet count     208,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     110 fL    
 Reticulocyte count     6.1%    
 Coombs test     Negative    
 Peripheral smear     Normal

choices.text: Maternal history of parvovirus B19 during pregnancy

questions.solution:
The twins in this vignette were born full-term but have vastly different presentations. One twin is 90th percentile for weight and ruddy, while the other twin is 23rd percentile and pale, which is concerning for twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS). Lab work confirms the diagnosis since there is an intertwin hemoglobin difference ≥ 8.0 g/dL and an intertwin reticulocyte ratio >1.7. TAPS occurs in monochorionic twin gestations. 

When newborn or infant anemia is due to blood loss, history can help identify the underlying cause. There may be a history of blood loss in the peripartum period such as caused by placental abruption, or history of excessive blood draws causing iatrogenic anemia. Monochorionic twin pregnancies are at risk for TAPS and twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

When anemia is secondary to red blood cell destruction, family history is important to obtain since certain conditions, such as sickle cell disease and thalassemia, are inherited. Jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly may be seen on physical exams. During pregnancy, the mother’s blood type should always be obtained since certain blood types (i.e., O and rhesus negative) are at higher risk for ABO incompatibility.   

Option Analysis

✅ Monochorionic twin gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal history of parvovirus B19 during pregnancy:
Incorrect: Intrauterine infection with parvovirus B19 can cause fetal anemia and other complications. In this vignette, one twin is anemic, and one twin is polycythemic, making the diagnosis of twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS) most likely.  
❌ Oligohydramnios:
Incorrect: Oligohydramnios occurs in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). Although TTTS is similar to twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS), the intertwin reticulocyte count ratio is >1.7 making TAPS the more likely diagnosis.  
❌ Maternal hemorrhage during delivery:
Incorrect: Maternal hemorrhage during delivery can cause neonatal anemia. This vignette with anemia in one twin and polycythemia in the other twin is more consistent with twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS). 
❌ Placental hypoplasia:
Incorrect: This vignette with anemia in one twin and polycythemia in the other twin suggests twin anemia-polycythemia sequence (TAPS). The placental findings in TAPS are small placental arteriovenous anastomoses with flow in a single direction and not placental hypoplasia.

questions.text: A 7-day-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for poor feeding, pallor, and mildly increased work of breathing. The infant was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks gestation. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 8 and 9. The baby had been feeding well until last night. Since then, she has been tired and uninterested in bottle feeding. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 170/min, and respirations are 52/min. Right upper extremity blood pressure is 84/55 mmHg and right upper extremity oxygen saturation is 99%. Right lower extremity blood pressure is 64/42 mm Hg and right lower extremity oxygen saturation is 94%. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and irritable and has increased work of breathing, she is tachypneic and exhibits belly breathing. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. A systolic murmur is heard and best appreciated at the left upper sternal border just below the left scapula. An S3 is present, and femoral pulses are faint. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 7-day-old girl has new-onset pallor, poor feeding, and increased work of breathing. Vital signs show a discrepancy between the pre- and post-ductal blood pressure and oxygen saturation. Physical examination findings include systolic murmur and faint femoral pulses. Together, these findings are consistent with critical coarctation of the aorta. The first step in management is administration of prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent.       

The first step in managing patients with acyanotic congenital heart defect is to perform an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment and stabilize the patient. This may include intubation, intravenous access, continuous vital sign monitoring, supplemental oxygen, and ionotropic support.       

Once the patient is stable, further evaluation including an echocardiogram is required to diagnose the underlying congenital heart defect. Subsequent management depends on the specific defect and the severity of symptoms. Some congenital heart defects require only frequent monitoring, whereas others require surgical intervention.      

Differential cyanosis refers to when the pre-ductal oxygen saturation is higher than the post-ductal. This finding is consistent with a critical left ventricular outflow tract obstruction such as critical aortic stenosis or critical coarctation of the aorta. Patients with these congenital heart defects can be dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus for systemic circulation, and therefore, PGE1 should be administered expeditiously in these cases.   

Option Analysis

✅ Prostaglandin E1 infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Surgery:
Incorrect: This patient has clinical evidence of critical coarctation of the aorta. The patient will require surgery, but the first step is prostaglandin E1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent. 
❌ Balloon angioplasty :
Incorrect: This patient has critical coarctation of the aorta. The first step is prostaglandin E1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent. The patient will need invasive intervention. Surgical repair is preferred over balloon angioplasty since surgical repair is associated with lower risk of reintervention. 
❌ Dopamine infusion:
Incorrect: This patient has critical coarctation of the aorta and initial intervention includes prostaglandin E1 infusion. If the patient had signs of associated heart failure, intravenous inotropic support (e.g., dopamine) would be necessary. This patient does not have associated findings to suggest heart failure. 
❌ Stent placement :
Incorrect: This patient has critical coarctation of the aorta and the first step is prostaglandin E1 infusion to keep the ductus arteriosus patent. Stent placement is occasionally performed in older patients following balloon angioplasty or surgery but would not be the initial treatment in this patient.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with his parent to the cardiologist for exertional chest pain and dyspnea for the past two months. He recently made his school’s track team and has been experiencing chest pain during sprint trials. He has not experienced palpitations. The patient has no significant past medical history. His parent reports that the patient’s biological father is followed by Cardiology for a heart murmur. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 97/min, blood pressure is 112/63 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99%. On physical examination, there is a 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. The murmur sounds softer with Valsalva. Pulses are 2+ and capillary refill is <2 seconds. Pulmonary examination is normal. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Blood pressure gradient > 20 mm Hg between upper and lower extremities

questions.solution:
This patient is a 14-year-old boy who presents for evaluation of dyspnea and chest pain with exertion. On physical examination, there is a systolic murmur heard at the right upper sternal border that softens with Valsalva maneuver. These findings are consistent with aortic stenosis which is often associated with bicuspid valves.           

Part of the evaluation of patients with acyanotic heart disease is to perform an echocardiogram to assess pulmonary blood flow. If the pulmonary blood flow is normal, congenital heart disease is considered obstructive. This includes non-critical coarctation, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis. Non-critical coarctation and aortic stenosis are associated with left ventricular hypertrophy while pulmonary stenosis is associated with right ventricular hypertrophy. Approximately 50% of patients with aortic stenosis have a bicuspid aortic valve.          

If there is an increase in pulmonary blood flow, congenital heart disease with left-to-right shunting should be considered. This includes atrial septal defects (ASDs), ventricular septal defects (VSDs), atrial ventricular septal defects (AVSDs, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). VSDs and AVSDs are associated with biventricular hypertrophy whereas ASDs are associated with right atrial enlargement.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bicuspid valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right ventricular hypertrophy:
Incorrect: This patient has aortic stenosis, which can cause left ventricular hypertrophy, not right ventricular hypertrophy. 
❌ Blood pressure gradient > 20 mm Hg between upper and lower extremities:
Incorrect: A blood pressure gradient between the upper and lower extremities is found in patients with coarctation of the aorta. This patient has aortic stenosis which is not associated with a blood pressure gradient between the upper and lower extremities. 
❌ Increased pulmonary blood flow:
Incorrect: Increased pulmonary blood flow is found in patients with atrial septal defects, ventricular septal defects, atrial ventricular septal defects, and patent ductus arteriosus. This patient has aortic stenosis which does not result in increased pulmonary blood flow.   
❌ Hypoplastic aortic arch:
Incorrect: A hypoplastic aortic arch is one type of critical coarctation. This patient's history and murmur are more consistent with aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the primary care office for a sports physical for participation on his high school basketball team. He is accompanied by his parent, and they have no current concerns. The patient does not have a significant past medical history and does not take any medication. His past surgical history consists of a left orchiectomy at 7 years of age following a bicycle accident. One of the patient’s parents drowned unexpectedly at age 39 while swimming. The other parent is 48 years old and has no significant past medical history. The patient does not have siblings. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 81/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 116/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 20 kg/m2 (57th percentile for age). Cardiovascular examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur at the left sternal border which increases in intensity with Valsalva maneuver. Musculoskeletal and neurological examinations are within normal limits. A chaperoned genital examination confirms the absence of the left testicle but is otherwise normal. Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates non-specific ST changes. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Do not authorize sports participation and order an echocardiogram
Authorize sports participation with protective gear
Authorize sports participation with cardiology follow-up
Do not authorize sports participation and order genetic testing
Do not authorize sports participation and order chest computed tomography

questions.solution:
This patient who is found to have a heart murmur, ECG abnormalities, and a family history of unexplained drowning should be evaluated for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) with an echocardiogram. He should not be authorized to participate in sports until HCM has been ruled out.        

The goal of the sports physical is to determine whether there are features suggestive of a condition that would make sports participation unsafe. For example, prior concussions that caused severe or prolonged symptoms, were recent, or associated with other prior brain injuries would place a patient at considerable risk for participation in contact sports.         

Phenotypic features of the connective tissue disorder Marfan syndrome, such as arachnodactyly, tall stature, or pectus excavatum, should prompt further evaluation before a patient is authorized to participate in sports, since patients with this condition are at risk of aortic dissection and sudden death.         

Family history, symptoms, or examination findings concerning for HCM also require further investigation, as this genetic heart condition is associated with sudden cardiac death. Symptoms of unexplained syncope, chest pain, palpitations, dizziness, or shortness of breath are all concerning for HCM and warrant further evaluation. Features to look for include family history of unexplained syncope or sudden cardiac death, especially in family members under the age of 50 years. An unexpected death attributed to drowning can also signal a cardiac event. The murmur of HCM is usually heard best at the left sternal border and is described as a harsh systolic murmur that increases in intensity during Valsalva or after standing. ECG findings can be variable, or normal; therefore, the history and physical should be used to determine if further evaluation is necessary before authorizing participation in sports. Recent musculoskeletal symptoms or injuries, with or without neurologic manifestations, should also be a red flag indicating that participation in sports may be unsafe without further workups.    

Option Analysis

✅ Do not authorize sports participation and order an echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Authorize sports participation with protective gear:
Incorrect: This athlete will need to use protective gear given his history of orchiectomy. However, given his parent’s unexpected drowning at an early age and the harsh systolic murmur heard on cardiovascular examination and ECG findings, an echocardiogram should be performed prior to authorization for sports participation.  
❌ Authorize sports participation with cardiology follow-up:
Incorrect: Athletes with physical exam and ECG findings that are consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) (e.g., harsh systolic murmur, non-specific ST changes) should not be authorized to participate in sports until the condition has been ruled out via additional testing, with an echocardiogram.  
❌ Do not authorize sports participation and order genetic testing:
Incorrect: Genetic testing can help narrow the cause of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) in patients with an established diagnosis; however, this patient has not yet had an echocardiogram to establish the diagnosis.
❌ Do not authorize sports participation and order chest computed tomography:
Incorrect: Chest computed tomography may be helpful for evaluating patients who potentially have Marfan syndrome which is a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue that can also present with heart problems. However, this patient does not have features suggestive of Marfan syndrome.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the primary care office for a sports physical for participation in baseball. He is a new patient to the practice and is accompanied by his parent. Medical records from the previous provider have not arrived yet. The patient and his parent have no current concerns. The patient has never had a concussion and does not experience exertional symptoms with exercise. He has no family history of sudden death or cardiac disorders. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 70/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 21 kg/m2 (46th percentile for age). The patient is alert and conversant. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Abdominal, musculoskeletal, and neurologic examinations are normal. Which of the following additional findings would be a contraindication to participating in sports?
questions.solution:
An important part of the sports participation physical is evaluation for cardiovascular conditions with a comprehensive personal and family history, cardiac examination, and evaluation of peripheral pulses. The finding of a brachial-femoral delay would suggest aortic coarctation, which would be a contraindication to participation in sports.        

The goal of a pre-participation sports physical is to identify potential underlying conditions that may increase an athlete’s risk of injury, illness, or death. Three main categories to consider are: musculoskeletal, neurologic, and cardiovascular.        

Musculoskeletal concerns that may make it unsafe for patients to participate in sports include recent injuries, joint instability, and limitations in range of motion or strength. Neurological concerns include recent concussion, ongoing neurologic symptoms, prior spinal injuries, and prior brachial plexus injuries. Cardiovascular concerns include recent cardiac symptoms, family history of genetic cardiac conditions or sudden death at an age younger than 50 years, hypertension, pathologic murmur, stigmata of Marfan syndrome, and brachial-femoral delay.        

When any condition is found either through history or physical examination that makes sports participation unsafe, the child should not be cleared for participation and appropriate follow-up should be arranged. Care should also be taken to not restrict a child unnecessarily, as patients with many chronic physical and mental health conditions can still safely participate in sports if adequate accommodation is provided.    

Option Analysis

✅ Brachial-femoral delay:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Severe allergy to peanuts:
Incorrect: Children with a history of severe allergies can be conditionally qualified to participate in sports. However, they should always have access to an epinephrine injector during sports participation.  
❌ Sickle cell trait:
Incorrect: Patients with sickle cell trait can be conditionally qualified to participate in sports. Because they are at risk of exertional rhabdomyolysis, they should take frequent rest and water breaks to avoid overexertion and dehydration. 
❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Children with asthma can be conditionally qualified to participate in sports. They must be given immediate access to an albuterol inhaler during all sports activities. 
❌ Diabetes:
Incorrect: Patients with diabetes can be conditionally qualified to participate in sports if they are provided with immediate access to glucose and glucagon during all sporting activities, to use in the event of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 3300-g (7.2-lb) newborn boy is delivered at term and is noted to be cyanotic at birth. The parent did not have prenatal care during her pregnancy and has a past medical history of bipolar disorder for which she takes lithium inconsistently. Temperature is 36.8�C (98.2�F), heart rate is 210/min, respirations are 70/min, blood pressure is 65/36 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 75% on room air. Physical examination reveals cyanosis and intercostal and subcostal retractions. Cardiac examination reveals a holosystolic murmur and a gallop. Abdominal examination is significant for a liver edge that is 5 cm below the costal margin. Chest x-ray shows massive cardiomegaly with a “box-shaped” appearance of the heart. Which of the following findings on the echocardiogram will confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Aorta arising from the right ventricle
Downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle
Pulmonary veins draining to the right atrium

questions.solution:
This neonate who is born with cyanosis, respiratory distress, a systolic murmur from tricuspid regurgitation, hepatomegaly, and chest X-ray findings of cardiomegaly and a “box-shaped” heart most likely has Ebstein anomaly. An echocardiogram showing a downward displaced tricuspid valve in the right ventricle would confirm the diagnosis.            

Ebstein anomaly can be genetic or acquired. Babies of mothers taking lithium during early pregnancy can present at birth with Ebstein anomaly. Newborns with Ebstein anomaly typically are born with significant respiratory distress and signs of congestive heart failure such as hepatomegaly and edema. Chest X-ray reveals massive cardiomegaly with a characteristic ‘box shape’ appearance, and echocardiogram demonstrates downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, right atrial enlargement, and right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With these findings, the diagnosis of Ebstein anomaly can be confirmed.   

Option Analysis

❌ Aorta arising from the right ventricle :
Incorrect: Aorta arising from the right ventricle is associated with transposition of the great arteries which typically presents with tachypnea in newborns in the first 12 hours of life. This patient's presentation of cyanosis at birth holosystolic murmur and chest X-ray showing a "box-shaped" heart from massive cardiomegaly is more consistent with Ebstein anomaly. 
✅ Downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Overriding aorta  :
Incorrect: An overriding aorta is seen with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which can be associated with DiGeorge syndrome. Chest x-ray typically shows the pathognomonic “boot-shaped” heart. This patient with cyanosis at birth, murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, and chest X-ray showing a "box-shaped" from massive cardiomegaly, more likely has Ebstein anomaly. 
❌ Hypoplastic left atrium :
Incorrect: Hypoplastic left atrium is seen in patients with hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) who are typically cyanotic with signs of poor perfusion on the first day of life. The findings of cyanosis at birth and history of maternal lithium use during pregnancy, along with murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, chest x-ray findings of a "box-shaped" heart are more consistent with Ebstein anomaly. 
❌ Pulmonary veins draining to the right atrium  :
Incorrect: Pulmonary veins draining to the right atrium is seen with total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage (TAPVD). Newborns with TAPVD typically present with profound respiratory distress and rapid deterioration without murmur on cardiac examination. The findings of cyanosis at birth and history of maternal lithium use during pregnancy, murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, with chest x-ray showing a "box-shaped" heart are more consistent with the diagnosis of Ebstein anomaly.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. There is no significant past medical history. Her parents report she is enthusiastic about eating a variety of foods and is hitting developmental milestones. They have no concerns during this visit. She has been in the lower percentiles on the growth curve since birth, but consistently trends at the same level. Today the patient’s height is 10th percentile and weight is 5th percentile. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 122/min, blood pressure is 89/49, respirations are 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 99%. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing, and in no acute distress. Heart rate is regular, there is a fixed split S2, and a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting for a well child visit is found on examination to have a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border and a fixed split S2. These findings are consistent with an atrial septal defect. The best next step is to perform an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis.        

For stable pediatric patients who present with a heart murmur, a focused history and physical examination should be performed. It is important to note whether the patient is experiencing chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, palpitations, or syncope. Newborns with a murmur should be assessed for difficulty feeding and cyanosis. Family history is also important since some heart defects are inherited.       

On physical examination, murmurs are primarily described based on the following characteristics: intensity, location, timing, quality, radiation, and whether positional changes affect the murmur. The intensity of murmurs ranges from I to VI, where grade I is barely audible, and grade VI can be heard with the stethoscope barely touching the chest wall. It should be noted where on the chest the murmur is best heard, whether it radiates to another location, and when it occurs in the cardiac cycle. Murmur quality describes the characteristics of the sound, such as musical or vibratory, blowing, harsh and rumbling. Positional changes may increase or decrease the intensity of the murmur.        

Innocent murmurs often do not require additional evaluation. If there is concern that a murmur is not innocent, the next step is the evaluation is to perform an echocardiogram.   

Option Analysis

✅ Echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pre- and post-ductal oxygen saturation:
Incorrect: Pre- and post-ductal oxygen saturation levels are used in newborns to assess for critical congenital heart defects that cause hypoxia. This patient’s murmur is consistent with atrial septal defect, which should be confirmed with an echocardiogram. 
❌ Reassurance :
Incorrect: This patient’s murmur is most consistent with an atrial septal defect which should be confirmed by echocardiogram. Reassurance without further evaluation is not appropriate as this is not an innocent murmur. 
❌ Electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: This patient’s murmur is consistent with a structural anomaly, specifically atrial septal defect. An echocardiogram is required to make this diagnosis, not an electrocardiogram. 
❌ Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: This patient’s murmur is consistent with atrial septal defect. The next best step is to obtain an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a weight check since he has not yet returned to his birth weight. Parents report that he has not been feeding well, and he tires quickly while bottle feeding. They have noticed mild increased work of breathing. He was born at 38 weeks 2 days gestation. The pregnancy was complicated by an abnormal prenatal ultrasound showing a moderate-large defect in the cardiac ventricular septum. Delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 9 and 9. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, respirations are 54/min, and oxygen saturation is 97%. On physical examination, the anterior fontanelle is open and flat. There is mild tachypnea, belly breathing, and intercostal retractions. Which of the following murmurs is most likely to be heard on examination?

choices.text: Holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border
Systolic murmur with a widely fixed and split S2 heard best at the left upper sternal border
Systolic murmur radiating to the back
Continuous machine-like murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border with radiation to the back
Systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border, that is softer with Valsalva

questions.solution:
This patient has a known ventricular septal defect (VSD) that was diagnosed on a prenatal ultrasound. He is now presenting with poor weight gain, difficulty feeding, and increased work of breathing consistent with early heart failure. The murmur associated with a VSD is a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.        

Patients with acyanotic congenital heart defects can present with a wide array of symptoms.  Patients can be asymptomatic, but they can also have poor feeding, lethargy, exercise intolerance, chest pain, and respiratory distress. It is important to review prenatal records as prenatal ultrasounds can diagnose acyanotic congenital heart defects.        
Patients with critical left ventricular outflow tract obstructions may present as critically ill around two weeks of age due to closure of the ductus arteriosus. Physical examination findings can include signs and symptoms of shock. Other types of acyanotic congenital heart defects present with murmurs and possibly heart failure symptoms (e.g., tachypnea and hepatomegaly). The description of the murmur can help diagnose the type of congenital heart defect. There are also many genetic syndromes with characteristic phenotypic features associated with congenital heart defects. For example, in Williams syndrome, patients can have a full face, a broad forehead, rounded cheeks, and a depressed nasal bridge with anteversion of the nares and associated supravalvular aortic stenosis.        

Vital signs play a key role in the initial evaluation. A pre- and post-ductal oxygen saturation provides information about the oxygenation of the systemic circulation before and after the ductus arteriosus inserts into the aorta. Patients with a critical left ventricular outflow obstruction can have a pre-ductal oxygen saturation that is higher than the post-ductal oxygen saturation. Four extremity blood pressures can help diagnose coarctation as a blood pressure gradient of 20 mmHg or more between the upper and lower extremities is consistent with coarctation of the aorta.   

Option Analysis

✅ Holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Systolic murmur with a widely fixed and split S2 heard best at the left upper sternal border:
Incorrect: An atrial septal defect presents as a systolic murmur with a widely fixed and split S2 heard best at the left upper sternal border. However, this patient has a diagnosed ventricular septal defect which presents with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.   
❌ Systolic murmur radiating to the back:
Incorrect: Pulmonary stenosis presents as a systolic murmur radiating to the back. This patient has a diagnosed ventricular septal defect which presents with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. 
❌ Continuous machine-like murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border with radiation to the back:
Incorrect: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) presents with a continuous machine-like murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border with radiation to the back. This patient has a ventricular septal defect which presents with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. 
❌ Systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border, that is softer with Valsalva:
Incorrect: Aortic stenosis presents as a systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border that becomes softer with Valsalva. This patient has a ventricular septal defect which presents with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.

questions.text:
A newborn girl is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation. The pregnancy and delivery are without complications. Examination of the newborn after delivery reveals a cleft lip. On the second day of life, the newborn is noted to be cyanotic. Temperature is 36.8�C (98.2�F), heart rate is 180/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, blood pressure is 78/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals cyanotic lips, cleft lip, micrognathia, sternal retractions, and nasal flaring. Cardiac examination is significant for a single loud S2 with a systolic ejection click at the left sternal border. There are bounding peripheral pulses bilaterally. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? 


Reproduced from: Statdx
questions.solution:
This neonate who became cyanotic on day 2 of life is found to have a single loud S2, bounding peripheral pulses, and increased pulmonary vascularity and cardiomegaly on chest x-ray. He also has a cleft lip and micrognathia suggestive of DiGeorge or velocardiofacial syndrome. Most patients with DiGeorge syndrome have congenital heart disease (CHD). The findings in this patient are consistent with truncus arteriosus, which can be confirmed with an echocardiogram showing a single arterial trunk supplying the systemic and pulmonary circulations and truncal artery overlying a ventricular septal defect (VSD).       

When evaluating patients with suspected CHD, it is important to obtain maternal, prenatal, and family history. Physical exam should focus on the presence and characteristics of heart sounds and murmurs. All neonates with suspected CHD should have peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) measured in both preductal (right hand) and postductal (either foot) locations to assess for cyanosis and differential cyanosis. Universal screening of newborns with pulse oximetry is offered in most hospitals. ECG should be performed, although it may be normal during the neonatal period, and it may show only nonspecific abnormalities. However, some CHDs are associated with specific ECG patterns.       

Chest x-ray should be performed and can give indications of the underlying CHD. In right-sided obstructive lesions (e.g., TOF), pulmonary vascular markings are usually decreased. Increased pulmonary vascular markings can be seen in the truncus arteriosus as pulmonary vascular resistance falls after delivery. Increased vascular marking from Pulmonary venous congestion and edema due to heart failure may be seen with obstructed total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) and in patients with heart failure due to left-sided obstructive lesions (e.g., HLHS).        

Echocardiograms can confirm the diagnosis of CHD and determine the type of lesions present. Additionally, when patients present with cyanosis and likely congenital heart disease, it is important to determine if the CHD is ductal dependent because, without administration of prostaglandins, the ductus arteriosus will close and lead to potentially life-threatening consequences within the first few days of life.   

Option Analysis

❌ Cardiac catheterization  :
Incorrect: Cardiac catheterization examines structures not visualized by echocardiography or for procedures like balloon septostomy. This patient has features of truncus arteriosus, and an echocardiogram, not cardiac catheterization, is used to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Echocardiogram :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Electrocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Electrocardiogram (ECG) can show indications of right, left, or biventricular hypertrophy in patients with congenital heart disease (CHD). However, it is not used to make a diagnosis of CHD. This patient likely has truncus arteriosus, and an electrocardiogram should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Hyperoxia test  :
Incorrect: A hyperoxia test was historically used to distinguish cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD) from pulmonary disease. Patients with cyanotic CHD are unable to increase their arterial blood partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) during administration of 100% oxygen. For this patient with likely truncus arteriosus, an echocardiogram is used to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Microsomal analysis :
Incorrect: Microsomal analysis can confirm the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome which can be associated with truncus arteriosus. However, an echocardiogram is needed to confirm the diagnosis of truncus arteriosus.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. Parents report that he has been doing well and they have no concerns. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 124/min, blood pressure is 88/43 mm Hg, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 100%. On physical examination, there is a mildly increased distance between the eyes and downward-slanting palpebral fissures. He has a webbed neck and pectus excavatum. On cardiac examination, there is a 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border with radiation to the back. Which of the following tests is recommended to confirm the most likely cardiac condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has phenotypic features consistent with Noonan syndrome, including hypertelorism, downward-slanting palpebral fissures, webbed neck, and pectus excavatum. A systolic murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border with radiation to the back is consistent with pulmonary stenosis which can be seen in patients with Noonan syndrome. Diagnosis of pulmonary stenosis is best made via echocardiogram.        

Echocardiograms can be used to diagnose acyanotic congenital heart disease. An echocardiogram is used to assess pulmonary blood flow and identify specific cardiac abnormalities. If the pulmonary blood flow is normal, congenital heart disease is considered obstructive. This includes non-critical coarctation, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis.        

If there is an increase in pulmonary blood flow, congenital heart diseases with left-to-right shunting should be considered. These include atrial septal defects (ASDs), ventricular septal defects (VSDs), atrial ventricular septal defects (AVSDs, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). In addition to assessing pulmonary blood flow, an echocardiogram is used to visualize valvular defects, septal defects, narrowing of the aorta, and patent ductus arteriosus, and to diagnose other specific congenital heart defects.        

Even though most patients with congenital heart disease will have an electrocardiogram and chest x-ray performed, these tests are not diagnostic, and echocardiogram is required. If the diagnosis remains uncertain after echocardiogram, additional imaging modalities such as magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography can be used.   

Option Analysis

✅ Echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Four extremity blood pressure:
Incorrect: Four extremity blood pressures are used to identify coarctation of the aorta. This patient likely has Noonan syndrome with pulmonary stenosis; four extremity blood pressures will be normal. An echocardiogram is utilized to diagnose pulmonary stenosis. 
❌ Cardiac MRI:
Incorrect: A cardiac MRI can diagnose pulmonary stenosis but is not the first-line recommended test. Echocardiogram is recommended first to confirm the presence of pulmonary stenosis. If echocardiogram is unable to confirm a diagnosis, cardiac MRI may be performed. 
❌ Genetic testing:
Incorrect: This patient likely has Noonan syndrome, which can be diagnosed via genetic testing. An echocardiogram should be performed to diagnose the likely underlying cardiac defect. 
❌ Electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: This patient has a murmur consistent with pulmonary stenosis. An electrocardiogram can be normal in mild pulmonary stenosis, or it may show signs of right axis deviation and ventricular hypertrophy in severe cases. It is not utilized for diagnostic testing for pulmonary stenosis.
